title: What is optical fiber made of? - Quora

response.answer_text: Surely the word fiber is not new for you, is it? Here is a fiber page that you could visit right now, just in case you don't know what fibers are. Many polymers can form neat fibers, as long as certain intermolecular forces can occur between chains, holding them together in a crystal-like fashion. Polymer fibers are strong materials with excellent tensile strength, which makes them very useful as textiles. But have optical fibers something to do with those fibers we are talking about? Well, yes and no. In fact, optical fibers have polymers in their composition. However, the term optical fiber doesn't tell us anything about the polymers, but about two transparent, dielectric tubes or cylinders, one surrounding the other, like this: Sound odd? What if we add that those optical fibers are light guides, which can be used to conduct electromagnetic energy at optical wavelengths? For a better understanding of all this, we'll need to refresh some physics. Back in the 1870s, British scientist John Tyndall performed a demonstration in which he showed light guiding by means of a curved stream of water flowing from an illuminated tank. Between 1900 and 1930 numerous experiments followed Tyndall's demonstration. It was discovered that bent thin glass rods not only could transmit light but using a bundle of glass rods (or optical fibers, as they were called later) complete images could be carried as well. What type of phenomenon was involved in these sensational findings? Well, it was just reflection, total internal reflection, as the walls of the thin fiber acted like mirrors in which the incident light bounced back and forth. You have many examples of total internal reflection in your everyday life. Just look for down asphalt road on a hot, sunny day, and you should see the reflection from the road surface as if the road had become a mirror. Well, it has due to the same property that causes internal reflection: if the light hits at a low enough angle, it can't penetrate the surface and just bounces off. Weird, hey? This reflection, governed by Snell's law, is made possible due to the differences between the refractive index of the glass and the air, the latter having the lowest value. However, the usefulness of light guidance would not be completely appreciated until 1950, when many scientists began to think about its potential applications. They were smart enough to understand that such applications ranged from medicine, enabling the visualization of inaccessible regions of the human body, to communication networks, in place of metal wires. But there were a number of drawbacks that arose in those first applications: light couldn't be carried too far, and the transmitted images came pretty poor and distorted. That was because the fibers had no coating at all surrounding them to increase the difference in the refractive index. For that reason, if such fibers got wet, for example, the glass-air interface didn't remain fixed and the way the light reflected inside was changed. Only in the mid-50s, Dutch Abraham van Heel designed a covering layer surrounding the fiber with another cylinder of glass, of the lower refractive index than that in the middle. This way, the total reflection was not affected by water, dirt, or other contamination. Finally, a third layer was added, in order to protect the glass fiber from damage and to make it easier to handle. Guess what type of material was used in this third layer?

It turns out that a complete answer to your question is almost impossible, simply because there are a very large variety of answers depending on the type of fiber, plus the fact that almost all of the formulations are proprietary. Different fibers have different properties, depending on the end properties that are required of the fiber. These properties are controlled by changing the particular ingredients and the fiber manufacturing process itself.
